properties.Name: Douglas Treaty signed
properties.Description: The establishment of the colony of Vancouver Island in 1849 was followed by land purchases from First Nations and the signing of the Douglas Treaty throughout the 1850's. An important distinction to make is that Indigenous Peoples in southern Vancouver Island and around Port Hardy negoited the terms of such treaties orally and the written document was created after the fact. James Douglas provided a few materials good such as cash, clothing and blankets and agrees that signatories and their descendants would retain their village sites and fields as well as the “liberty to hunt over unoccupied lands” and the right to “carry on their fisheries as formerly.”. These terms were in no way upheld by the Hudsons Bay Company and later the government of Canada.

properties.Name: Map of Camosack
properties.Description: A map of Camosack, the anglisized version of the Lekwungen word q̓əm̓ásəŋ, created by cartographer Adolphus Lee Lewis for use by the Hudsons Bay Company

properties.Name: Competitive Swimming in the Gorge
properties.Description: In 1893, the director of the local YMCA begins organizing swimming competitions within a log enclosed swimming tank moored next to the Point Ellice Bridge.

properties.Name: BC Electric Railway Company buys land on the Gorge
properties.Description: In 1904, the British Columbia Electric Railway Company bought 20 acres of land along the Gorge Waterway from the Hudsons Bay Company. This change of ownership kicked off a future of this land as a space of public enjoyment and recreation.

properties.Name: Creation of Tramway Gorge Park
properties.Description: Funded by the BC Electric Company, Tramway Gorge Park was created in 1905 and boasted various amusement and recreation for the public. Variety shows, a roller coaster, merry-go-round, concession, dance hall and boathouses contributed to the parks popularity.

properties.Name: Opening of the Japanese Tea Gardens
properties.Description: Hayato Takata and Yoshitaro Kishida, two prominent figures in the Victoria Japanese-Canadian community raised $5,000 in hopes of opening a Japanese Tea Garden in Tramway Park. Kishida's father, a professional gardener in Japan, designed the grounds and teahouse. The Japanese Tea House was extremely popular in the following three decades.

properties.Name: 7th Annual BC Amateur Swimming Championships
properties.Description: The 7th Annual BC Amateur Swimming Championships are held at Gorge Beach, a very popular swim spot especially into the 1920's. The creation of the Victoria Amateur Swim Club and the two story bath pavilion known as the Free indicate the popularity of swimming in the Gorge at this time.

properties.Name: Victoria Harbour Migratory Bird Sanctaury
properties.Description: The Gorge Waterway becomes part of the Victoria Migratory Bird Sanctuary to preserve important wintering habitat for millions of birds on their annual migrations. The 'Friends of the Victoria Harbour Migratory Bird Sanctuary' celebrated 100 years of the VHMBS in 2023.

properties.Name: Gorge swimming closed to the public
properties.Description: The Gorge was closed to swimming after a joint inspection of water quality by the City of Victoria and the Municipality of Saanich found the waterway polluted.

properties.Name: Township of Esquimalt install drainage system
properties.Description: A drainage system was installed that emptied directly into the Gorge above the popular swimming spot at the Free. Pollution increased in following years as industrial development and septic tank runoff intensified.

properties.Name: Typhoid outbreak from polluted waterway
properties.Description: The pollution in the Gorge is linked to typhoid outbreaks further degrading the reputation of the once pristine waterway.

properties.Name: Japanese Tea Garden looted
properties.Description: During World War II, the Takata family, along with all people of Japanese descent in BC, were forced into internment camps, leaving their property to be looted and destroyed in acts of anti-Asian racism by local residents.

properties.Name: Gorge Waterway Improvement Association created
properties.Description: Lead by Victoria Alderman and Geoffery Edgelow, the Gorge Waterway Improvement Association (GWIA) begin to clean up the waterway. In partnership with the City of Victoria and the Township of Esquimalt, septic outflow is significant reduced by the addition of sewer systems between 1956 and 1958.

properties.Name: The Gorge is given a clean bill of health
properties.Description: Due to cleanup efforts by the GWIA, Victoria and Esquimalt, the Gorge Waterway is declared safe to swim in once again.

properties.Name: Kinsmen Gorge Park officially opened
properties.Description: Funded by the Victoria Kinsmen Club, Kinsmen Gorge Park officially opened and a portion of Gorge Creek was dredged out to create a concrete salt water pool. This pool was chlorinated due to concerns about water quality and flushed untreated back into the waterway at the end of the season.

properties.Name: Water quality concerns resurfaced
properties.Description: Swimming continued despite growing concerns of water quality due to increased development along the Gorge and lack of suitable sewage treatment infastructure.

properties.Name: Boat regattas during the Gold Rush
properties.Description: Initialized by American vistors celebrating July 4th, the American Day of Independence, these regattas were eventually moved to May 24th, Queen Victoria's Birthday. Races originally included Navy personel, local clubs, Chinese boat races and Indigenous canoe races. These events became more segragated as time went on.

properties.Name: Songhees canoe wins regatta
properties.Description: Boat builders Marshall Harry, SȾÁ,UTW̱ (Tsawout) band members and Edwin Underwood create a new canoe, a hybridization of local Indigenous designs and long English racing canoes. In 1876, it was in this hybrid canoe that a Songhees team won a 3.2km race in approximately 15 minutes.

properties.Name: Father and son take action to clean up the waterway
properties.Description: After urban development, poor waste management and lack of awareness, the Gorge again becomes incredibly polluted throughout the 70's and 80's. In 1994, a father-son duo started removing debris from the Gorge in an effort to address the pollution.

properties.Name: Veins of Life Watershed Society is born
properties.Description: Inspired by the cleanup efforts initiated in 1994, a core group of volunteers registered the Veins of Life Watershed Society as a non-profit with the goal to restore the watershed.

properties.Name: The Gorge Waterway Action Society is created
properties.Description: Founded by a group of concerned community members, the Gorge Waterway Action Society's mission was to protect, restore and improve the Gorge Waterway.

properties.Name: GWAS membership grows
properties.Description: By 1995, GWAS was made up of 175 volunteers dedicated to restoring the Gorge and building partnerships with the Township of Esquimalt, the City of Victoria, the Province of BC and other environmental NGOs.

properties.Name: The Gorge is given a clean bill of health
properties.Description: After extensive efforts by various non-profit groups, concerned community members and dedicated volunteers, the Gorge is given a clean bill of health and swimming is once again safe.

properties.Name: Gorge Creek is daylighted
properties.Description: As part of a major restoration project, the culvert that contained Gorge Creek underground for multiple decades is removed and Gorge Creek is allowed to flow freely into channels that accomodate tides, native plants and terrestrial species.

properties.Name: Indigenous canoe race returns to Inner Harbour
properties.Description: Organized by the Esquimalt and Songhees Nations and the Greater Victoria Harbour Authority, 5 Nations participated in the first war canoe races held in the Inner Harbour in over 100 years.

properties.Name: The Japanese Tea Gardens re-opens
properties.Description: The Township of Esquimalt refurbishes the Japanese Tea Gardens, installing a traditional Japanese entry gate and rejuvinating the gardens to their former glory under the care of the Takata family. In October 2009, the Township hosted an official re-opening ceremony including a Buddhist garden blessing and performances by the Uminari Drum Group and the Furusato Dancers.

properties.Name: The Gorge Waterway Nature House is established
properties.Description: In partnership with the World Fisheries Trust and the Township of Esquimalt, the Kinsmen pool concession was transformed into the Gorge Waterway Nature House, a place of outreach, education and community gatherings.

properties.Name: The Gorge Waterway Nature House becomes the heart of GWAS
properties.Description: The Nature House becomes fully operated by the Gorge Waterway Action Society in tandem with the creation of Nature Interpreter program. Our Nature Interpreters provide environmental education for park visitors, develop activities for school visits and organize outreach events.

properties.Name: The Gorge Waterway Action Society continues to grow
properties.Description: GWAS expands its impact with the creation of the Restoration Program in 2017, followed by the Biology Program in 2018, Indigenous Youth Program in 2022 and Climate Interpreter Program in 2023. The Nature House is the hub at which staff and community members take part in restoration events, biological monitoring and environmental education events.

properties.Name: Swim platform at Banfield Park
properties.Description: In mid-July 2022, Aryze Developments launched a floating public swim dock featuring a Japanese katsura tree, positioned near the Banfield public dock. In 2022, the City committed $300,000 to construct another swimming platform and install buoys to designate a protected swim zone. In 2024, further enhancements were established, such as a life-jacket loaner station, anchored buoys for a recreational swimming area, and additional swim steps to improve accessibility and safety.

properties.Name: Selkirk Trestle
properties.Description: Originally built as a railway bridge to facilitate the unloading of logs from Vancouver Island's logging industry, the Selkirk Trestle enabled logs to be pushed off trains directly into the Gorge. Tugboats then transported the logs to the nearby pulp mill. Today, it serves as a segment of the Galloping Goose Trail, popular for cycling commuters and recreational runners and walkers of all speeds. Constructed from fir and hemlock, this 300-meter-long trestle includes a movable middle section that can be raised to allow tall ships to pass underneath.

properties.Name: Relocation of Craigflower Creek Olympia Oysters
properties.Description: The World Fisheries Trust collaborated with the Capital Regional District of Victoria (CRD) on a project to safeguard Olympia Oysters impacted by the Craigflower Bridge Replacement Project. These oysters were relocated from the bridge site to two designated oyster shell reefs located at Christie Point and Esquimalt Gorge Park.

properties.Name: Reefballs introduced for native oyster habitat
properties.Description: Three 350-pound hollow concrete artificial reefs (reefballs) were introduced into the Gorge, featuring large holes designed to facilitate water flow and promote oyster settlement, offering them a habitat above muddy substrates.

properties.Name: Gorge Creek upper settling pond
properties.Description: The upper settling pond is a key feature of the 2006 daylighting of Gorge Creek. Approximately 1/3 of the run-off from the Township of Esquimalt comes through this culvert, bringing with it many pollutants from roads and ditches. Most of the flow is diverted into the pond where it slows for sediment to settle out. Cattails, sedges, and rushes in and around the pond help to filter contaminants.

properties.Name: Eelgrass monitoring
properties.Description: Eelgrass is a keystone species which grows in shallow saltwater areas.  Microorganisms such as algae and bacteria grow on the surface of the eelgrass leaves, which provides food for many marine organisms. Monitoring of the health of eelgrass in the Gorge was initiated in 2022 and continues annually.

properties.Name: Sherwood Forest restoration
properties.Description: Sherwood Forest is the woodland East of the Nature House that hosts many restoration projects to support wildlife and forest health. Examples include invasive species removal, soil testing and the planting of native species with the hope of creating a forage food forest.

properties.Name: Indigenous Youth Program Stewardship Site
properties.Description: The Indigenous Youth Program Stewardship Site is designed as a place for the Esquimalt and Songhees Nations to gather, engage with, and learn about culturally significant plants. These two sites are continually cared for by Indigenous youth and GWAS staff.

properties.Name: Pollinator meadow
properties.Description: A 125 meter squared meadow that hosts at least 35 native plant species and many different pollinators. GWAS staff conducts both biophysical and pollinator surveys to better understand how to support native pollinators as they become more endangered.

properties.Name: 6-PPDQ monitoring
properties.Description: A toxic chemical shed by tires, 6-PPDQ is particularly lethal for salmon species. In an effort to understand the concentration of 6-PPDQ in Gorge Creek, GWAS has been testing annually in partnership with BC Conservation Foundation and VIU since 2023.

properties.Name: European Green Crab monitoring
properties.Description: Since 2022, GWAS has participated in the Department of Fisheries and Oceans’ European Green Crab Monitoring Project. European green crabs are a destructive invasive species that removes eelgrass very efficiently, destroying habitat for everything else in the Gorge. Unfortunately, teams caught adult European green crabs in the Gorge for the first time in August 2024 through the monitoring program. GWAS is working with the Department of Fisheries and Oceans and Peninsula Streams Society to remove as many as possible before the problem worsens. To prevent the spread of European Green Crabs, make sure to clean, drain, and dry off any watercraft according to BC Invasives.
